Award.AwardTitle: Photonic Curing of Semiconductor Nanocrystals for High-Performance Flexible Electronics

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
ABSTRACT:

Non-technical description:
The fundamental goal of this research is to make revolutionary advances in the emerging field of flexible electronics. The core building blocks of cell phones and tablet computers are computer chips that are fragile, rigid, and expensive to manufacture. In contrast, new materials and manufacturing methods are being explored that will enable these computer chips to be built on thin, flexible, plastic sheets. These flexible electronic systems that can bend, roll, fold, and move with the human body will enable tools that are simply not possible with rigid chips and circuits. Flexible displays, electronic textiles, biosensors, and wearable medical devices are just a few applications that will benefit from lightweight, low-cost, flexible electronic devices. In this research, the investigators will explore how nanometer-sized particles -small enough to fit 10,000 of them end to end across the width of a single human hair- can be heated with brief flashes of intense light to make superior materials for flexible electronics.
Technical description:
This research will explore novel materials and fabrication methods to enable high-performance flexible electronics. The investigators will synthesize solution-based electronic materials ("inks") of indium-gallium-zinc-oxide (IGZO), then fabricate flexible transistors by depositing the ink directly onto plastic substrates. After deposition onto the substrate, the materials undergo a heat treatment to improve their electrical characteristics. Higher temperatures generally result in higher quality materials, but the flexible plastic substrates typically cannot be heated above ~200C. A technique called photonic curing -using flash lamps to transiently heat the thin film to a high temperature without heating the substrate enough to cause damage- will be used to help address this tradeoff. The key research objective is to understand how the morphological and electronic properties of metal oxide nanocrystal thin films on flexible substrates are affected by photonic curing. That knowledge will be used to design high performance transistors on flexible substrates. The proposed research is a collaborative project between the principal investigator's research group at the University of Minnesota and NovaCentrix Corp., effectively bringing together expertise in nanomaterial synthesis, thin film characterization, and transistor design with the industry leader in photonic curing. The investigators will perform detailed characterizations of the materials and devices to achieve a fundamental physical understanding of how photonic curing affects the morphology, crystallinity, composition, and electronic characteristics of metal oxide nanocrystal thin films. This research will elucidate the physical mechanisms that lead to observed transistor behavior and identify the factors that limit thin-film transistor performance so they can be mitigated. A deeper fundamental understanding of photonic curing as an alternative to traditional thermal treatments of ceramic thin films could result in game-changing advances in a wide array of flexible electronic systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Transistors are the basic building blocks of all electronic devices. Though they can be understood most simply as an “on/off” switch, they can be combined by the billions to create anything from a simple amplifier to a computer processor. A thin-film transistor (TFT) is a specific type of transistor that can be manufactured on a low-cost material such as glass. TFTs control each individual pixel in the display of a smartphone, tablet, and television. The primary goal of this project was to produce high-performance thin-film transistors (TFTs) on flexible plastic substrates instead of glass. Flexible TFTs can provide circuits that are robust and lightweight, as well as enable electronic sensors and devices that can fold, bend, and roll up. Such sensors can be worn on the body or integrated into systems ranging from medical devices to smart homes.

 

 Printing solution-based materials onto low-cost substrates is an appealing manufacturing method for flexible electronics. However, achieving high-performance printed semiconductor materials currently requires annealing temperatures that are too high for most plastic substrates. To overcome this limitation, we combined Prof. Swisher’s expertise in nanomaterial synthesis and solution-processed electronics with Dr. Schroder’s industry-leading photonic curing tools at NovaCentrix. We utilized metal oxide semiconductors (e.g. In2O3, ZnO and In-Zn-O mixtures) as the channel material for TFTs. The Swisher group synthesized metal oxide nanocrystals and sol-gel inks to produce high-quality thin-film semiconductors for TFTs. At NovaCentrix, the thin films were processed using photonic curing: a non- equilibrium thermal treatment in which a very short, intense flash of broad-spectrum light heats the thin film so quickly that the substrate is not damaged. Our primary goal was to understand the fundamental physics behind photonic curing of metal oxide nanocrystals, and then leverage that knowledge to make dramatic improvements in the performance of transistors on flexible substrates.

 

In this project, photonic curing was used to rapidly and effectively convert metal oxide sol-gels into high-quality TFTs. We first explored the photonic curing process on glass substrates to better understand the important aspects of the device design. Indium oxide nanocrystals and sol-gel indium zinc oxide (IZO) TFTs were fabricated in Swisher’s lab and photonically cured at NovaCentrix. During curing, the IZO film reached a peak temperature of ~590 ̊C while the back of the substrate stayed near room temperature. The TFTs made using these photonically cured films exceeded the performance of samples annealed at 500 ̊C for 1 hr. The temperature gradient from the IZO film to the substrate during photonic curing is critically important as we move towards fabrication of high-quality oxide TFTs on low-cost plastic substrates. Preliminary results obtained during this project indicate that these metal oxide semiconductors can be processed on plastic substrates, and we are continuing to improve the processing and device performance.

 

This project offered valuable training and hands-on experience for graduate students in Swisher’s lab who closely collaborated with our industry partners at NovaCentrix. Other outreach efforts involved Swisher’s role as a mentor, particularly to support diversity in her department and in the broader field of electrical engineering. Through these interactions, Swisher has aimed to broaden the pipeline of students who pursue electrical engineering and other STEM majors, ultimately increasing participation among traditionally under-represented groups. In particular, this project gave Swisher the opportunity to mentor a female undergraduate student for 2 years who ultimately graduated from her department with honors and was accepted to a top-tier PhD program.
